messages.content: quiero hacer un git push, pero al clonar mi repositorio olvide colocar el Host que configurén en ~/.ssh/config para usar mi llave ssh

Entendido. Para solucionar esto, necesitamos actualizar la URL del repositorio remoto (`origin`) para que utilice el `Host` que configuraste.

Primero, voy a verificar tu configuración actual del remoto.

thoughts.subject: Considering Git Push Errors
thoughts.description: I've identified the core problem: the user's SSH configuration isn't aligned with the repository's URL, leading to `git push` failures. Now, I'm recalling the relevant SSH configuration files and commands to diagnose and resolve this issue, and the various git commands to facilitate the process. I'm focusing on the `~/.ssh/config` file's `Host` entries.

thoughts.description: I'm charting the next steps now. I've planned the overall approach, and I'm solidifying the interaction flow with the user. I'll start by examining the user's existing remote configuration with `git remote -v`. Then, I'll explain the disconnect between their SSH setup and repository URL. Finally, I'll gather the necessary `Host` information from the user to set the new URL and correct the `git push` issue.

thoughts.subject: Detailing Remote URL Update
thoughts.description: Okay, I've fleshed out the interaction sequence. I will begin by running `git remote -v` to reveal the existing configuration and confirm the issue. From there, I will present an explanation to the user and request the correct `Host` value. With that, I can formulate and then execute the `git remote set-url` command, subsequently verifying its success with another `git remote -v` execution.

thoughts.description: After analyzing the output of `git remote -v`, I need the user's custom `Host` from their SSH configuration. My next step involves directly asking the user for this value. I've crafted a clear and concise question to elicit this essential information, allowing me to construct the corrected `git remote set-url` command.

Subsequently, I'll clearly explain the underlying issue, focusing on the mismatch between the remote URL and the user's SSH configuration. The crucial step involves obtaining the custom `Host` value, which I'll use to formulate the `git remote set-url` command.

thoughts.description: I'm now finalizing the interaction and testing workflow. After receiving the user's `Host`, I'll craft and execute `git remote set-url`, providing a clear explanation of what is changing. Following that, I'll run `git remote -v` to confirm the update's success, then report the updated URL to the user, confirming that it is working properly.

thoughts.description: I've refined my strategy, planning out the interaction in more detail. After the initial `git remote -v` to confirm, I'll ask the user for their custom `Host`. Once obtained, I'll craft the `git remote set-url` command. Following execution, I'll verify with `git remote -v` and then present a confirmation message to the user. I'm confident that this method will succeed and provide the user with a smooth experience.

messages.content:
Ok, veo que la URL remota actual es `https://github.com/NelsonAguirre/illustrate.nvim.git`.

Para usar tu llave SSH, necesitamos cambiarla a una URL de tipo SSH (`git@...`).

¿Podrías decirme cuál es el `Host` que configuraste en tu `~/.ssh/config` para este repositorio? Con ese dato, construiré la URL correcta y la actualizaré.

thoughts.subject: Evaluating Git Remotes
thoughts.description: I've just examined the output of `git remote -v`. It's clear that the remote is set up with an HTTPS URL. The next step will be determining the user's ultimate goal, which appears to be using an SSH key for authentication.

thoughts.subject: Pinpointing the Hostname
thoughts.description:
\n\n

I've decided I must obtain the custom Host from the user's SSH config to proceed. I've also determined the user's username and repository from the existing HTTPS URL. Now, I'm composing the exact language I'll use to request the necessary hostname information from the user to construct the correct SSH URL.

thoughts.subject: Composing User Interaction
thoughts.description:
\n\n

I'm currently drafting the exact dialogue I'll use. I'll start by acknowledging the existing HTTPS setup, explaining the need for an SSH URL to leverage their key. Then, I'll ask for the `Host` value from their SSH config, providing an example URL for clarity. The goal is to get the information I need in the simplest, most direct way possible.

messages.content: Es: "github-NelsonAguirre" que obviamente apunta al host github.com
Perfecto. Ahora voy a actualizar la URL del remoto `origin` para que use tu configuración SSH.

thoughts.subject: Refining Remote URL
thoughts.description: I'm working on updating the remote URL. Right now, it's pointing to a standard GitHub URL, but the user wants to use a custom SSH host for this. I've got the username and the repository name, and I'm figuring out how to format the new URL to incorporate this. I'm considering the best way to do this.

thoughts.subject: Implementing the Command
thoughts.description: I've formulated the command: `git remote set-url origin git@github-NelsonAguirre:NelsonAguirre/illustrate.nvim.git`. Next, I'll craft a clear description for the user: "Actualizar la URL del remoto 'origin' para usar el Host de SSH personalizado." Finally, I plan to execute the command with the `run_shell_command` tool. A crucial step is verifying the successful URL update using `git remote -v`.

messages.content: Listo. Para confirmar, voy a verificar la configuración del remoto nuevamente.

thoughts.subject: Assessing Verification Needs
thoughts.description: I'm now focused on verifying the changes. I've already updated the remote URL using `git remote set-url`. The next step is to confirm these modifications. I've constructed the command `git remote -v` to display the updated remote URLs, and I'm ready to execute this.

thoughts.subject: Executing Verification Commands
thoughts.description: I've successfully constructed and executed the `git remote -v` command. This was done to verify the remote URL updates. The output should confirm the changes are as intended. I am now waiting for a response from the command to confirm the changes.

messages.content: La URL ha sido actualizada correctamente. Ahora puedes hacer `git push` y se usará tu configuración de SSH.

thoughts.subject: Solving User Issues
thoughts.description: I've nailed down the user's problem: a remote URL format blunder. Gathering the custom SSH host info was key. I've just fixed the URL using `git remote set-url`. Next, I'll check the fix's success with `git remote -v`.

thoughts.subject: Finalizing Resolution Details
thoughts.description: The issue is resolved! I've confirmed the fix using `git remote -v`, and the remote URL now reflects the correct format. I am ready to relay this solution to the user. This wraps up the entire troubleshooting process.
